question: And in your country, when people travel to different cities domestically, do they usually take a plane or a train?
transcript: I think they usually take a train because it is cheap and it does not take a lot of time to hold the security. So, just one, one or two steps to be sure I am a safe person. Okay, okay, good, good.

anti_overrating.reason: 'hold the security' (go through security). 'be sure I am a safe person' (ensure safety / check ID).

question: Now, what are some of the disadvantages of living near an airport?
transcript: I could say the, the, the biggest disadvantage living in a airport is noisy. There are a lot of flights departing and taking off. So it causes a lot of noisy and someone really complain about this kind of big sound. that is all I want to say. Okay, right, very good.

anti_overrating.reason: 'living in a airport' (near an airport). 'is noisy' (is noise / the noise). 'causes a lot of noisy' (noise). 'someone really complain' (people really complain).

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: Attempts to use complex sentences but these tend to be less accurate.
ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Manages to talk about familiar and unfamiliar topics but uses vocabulary with limited flexibility.

vocab_reason: Word form errors (noisy vs noise). Band 5.

question: And how is working in an airport different from working like in other places?

question: And what are some of your hobbies?

I am not really good at it but still as I learned golf I have, I have realized that it is not only that not only Does it require to have a physical strength but also you need to have the mental ability to concentrate for more than four hours. So, that kind of thing really made me go into golf and I am loving golf right now.

question: And have you ever forgotten something important?
transcript: I forget things all the time. For example, today this, this meeting with you and me, I have almost forgot until this morning, but I just suddenly, figured that I have to go to this place until 10 a.m. So, yeah, I forget things all the time, but still I, eventually I do everything that I have to do.

question: And how do you remember important things?
transcript: If it is super, super important, then obviously I cannot forget it because let us say that I am meeting with my family someday, then I would obviously know that I have to go to some place at some time. So, but if it is important but I could forget and in order to prevent that kind of thing, then I would write it down on my calendar or write it down on my cell phone or my laptop and put an alarm so that, you know, let us say that it takes about an hour to get that, get to that place. So, an hour before I put an alarm, ring it, if it rings, then I leave.

anti_overrating.reason: 'I put an alarm, ring it' (I set an alarm).

question: So how do you feel when you are praised?
transcript: I, there is a saying in Korea that, if you praise a whale can dance. A whale could even dance if someone praises you. So, I love getting praised. I love, people who acknowledge my ability or acknowledge my good personality or something like that. So I would say that I am always open to praising. I am I am really open to praising other people. So it is like a, communication. So it goes back and forth. Absolutely.

anti_overrating.reason: 'open to praising' (open to praise / open to being praised).

question: And when was the last time you praised someone?
transcript: One of my friends, is experiencing a very difficult time because of family issues. And, I knew that person for a very long time, over five years. In that course of time I never thought that this person would be a mature person I thought that she was very how should I immature very childish had a very childish behavior But, I realized that, when hardships came, she really was able to cope that difficulty and, solve that problem by herself. So I really praised her a lot. I never knew that I, I told her that I never knew that you could be that mature and, going forward no matter what.

question: So, how should I teach students?
transcript: I think basically a lecture would be a basic way to do, the most effective way, easiest way. But also, just free talking, communicating, just like you and me. So, I really think that the more you talk, the more you listen, the more you write, that is like the basis of every language skill. If you want to be good at it, you need to keep doing it. And English is essential in today's society, not only for, you know, exams or business, but also if you are traveling to a certain country, most people in that country will be able to speak some form of English. So you, you will be able to communicate with a lot of different people in a lot of different countries if you learn English. So in, in that kind of way, you need to learn English. my parents once said to me, if you want to have a good life, you need to be able to to do English in some sort of way, either in writing or listening or speaking. If you can do all of them, it will be the best, but not all, not for all, so. Okay, perfect. that is two minutes now. Nice one.

question: So when you were a kid, did you enjoy learning English?
transcript: The first three to four months it wasn easy because when I went to British International School Jakarta my peers were already good at pretty decent in speaking English but I could not speak a single word So I was a slow learner at that time But eventually I realized that I was a fast learner So I catched up everything that they did So at first it wasn easy but now it it it a natural thing to me Almost like my mother tongue nice one. question: Okay, so what do you think are the differences between online and face-to-face learning?
transcript: Online learning and face-to-face learning. I have told you that I have, I was a former instructor in another private academy located in some other local, some other place. I have experienced, I have taught in both ways, meeting a student from face-to-face and also through platforms like Zoom. I would say, in, in the more effective way to teach, the more effective way to learn, I would say it is, meeting from face to face. Because Zoom, I cannot check whether this student is concentrating in my, in the class or not. So, I just, deliver information in a one way, in a single way from me to the student. But I cannot really get much feedback of whether he or she is understanding what I am saying and whether they are catching up. So I think meeting face-to-face is more effective than online classes.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.grammar_text: Uses a full range of structures naturally and appropriately.
ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses language with natural and sophisticated control of lexical features.

question: And are there any advantages of online classes?
transcript: Yes, because once I have taught a student who was living in Canada, how would I be able to teach someone who is really far away if I do not have, like, Zoom or WebEx? So, in that point of view, you can transcend the geographic limitations and you will be able to communicate with anyone, anywhere on the planet. So, in that point of view, it is a good thing. Absolutely.

ielts_descriptor_alignment.vocabulary_text: Uses language with natural and sophisticated control of lexical features.

question: And do you think teachers should be funny when they teach?
transcript: That is a pretty tricky question because I am funny but at the same time I am pretty strict when I, when I taught the students because, some students, they think that they are just here to have fun, but actually they are here to learn. They need to be able to learn something from me. Then I would obviously have to be professional during the class. So if it is, if they are young, like elementary school, first grade, second grade, I would be more friendly and funny. But if they are like high school students, then I would be, you know, just driving them to study more, to learn more, and so on.

question: And what qualities do you think teachers should have?
transcript: They should be able to understand what the student lacks because the teacher exists to improve the student, to educate the students, to become, to make them become better. So they need to be able to know what the student needs and what the student has to do more in order to improve a certain skill. Either it could be math, it could be English, it could be reading comprehension whatsoever. So they need to, as they communicate with the student, as they teach the student, they should be able to know what that student needs to learn more. So yeah, it is a strategic point of view. Absolutely.

question: And which age group do you think is the best at learning new things?
transcript: The younger the better. The younger the better, I would say. I was three, four years old when I started learning English. I was late compared to my peers, but still, I am a foreigner, I am a Korean, and I am learning English at a very young age, three, four years old. That would be a very, very quick point of starting to learn English because my other friends that I met in Korea, they started learning English in elementary school or even middle school. So the earlier I think because also very young kids have the capacity have a bigger capacity to fill up their brains with new ideas and new concepts So I think the younger the better Yeah And do you think learning a language is mostly for like job opportunities and education or is it are there other reasons to as I said, if you want to have a good life, you need to be able to speak English. If you speak English, you can go almost anywhere on the planet. So you can travel either it is if it is business or just traveling or some other purpose studying you. The purpose does not matter because communication is established already. So you, if you want to have an international life, if you want to have a lot of opportunities in your life, then you should be able to look beyond Korea, your home country and look to other places.
